0.33.text: This is Buckingham Palace, which is the official residence of HerMajesty The Queen.

13.72.text: You're going to come with me for a tour, so please, come on in.

16.79.text:
You are now standing inside the Grand
Entrance of Buckingham Palace.

23.71.text:
Buckingham Palace is the home of Her
Majesty the Queen, the Duke of Edinburgh

28.11.text:
and the other members of the Royal
Family so it's a beautiful place.

31.79.text:
But still a working palace, that's what's
really important to remember.

36.45.text: My role as Master of the Household is a very ancient role.  It is over 400 years old.

41.12.text:
It started off with James I in 1603.  In
modern terms, I would say, people would

48.52.text:
call me the Chief Operations Officer for
The Queen.  I would now like to introduce

52.54.text: you to Anna Reynolds. Anna is the curator of paintings for

57.84.text:
Royal Collection Trust.  I'm going to take
you on an Expedition through Buckingham

62.06.text:
Palace today, pointing out some of the
highlights and showing you the various

65.42.text:
different rooms that make up the Palace.
This wasn't always a Palace.  Buckingham

69.92.text:
Palace wasn't always a palace, it was
actually originally a smaller house

73.15.text: called Buckingham House and it belonged to the Duke of Buckingham, which who it's named after.

77.39.text: It was bought as a private family home by George III.

83.36.text:
His son, George the IV decided that he
wanted to make it more magnificent and

87.34.text:
turn it into a palace.  He engaged the
architect John Nash to make changes to

93.54.text:
the palace and to make the rooms larger.
He actually changed the entrance hall here,

97.56.text:
he lowered the floor so the ceiling
would appear taller and he added the

101.82.text:
amazing flights of stairs that really
give you this sense of excitement as you

105.97.text:
move up into the rest of the State Rooms.
Something that you might spot are all

111.05.text:
the different marble columns that are
around this room. There were originally a

114.40.text:
hundred and four here in the Marble Hall -
that's why it's called the Marble Hall.

119.40.text: In 1829, one very very large block of marble was brought along the Thames.

124.81.text:
It actually weighed as much as two
double-decker buses, so you can imagine

128.24.text:
it took 17 horses to transport it here.
We're going to continue up the Grand

134.87.text:

things in the Palace is something you

and then covered in a very thin layer of

160.69.text:
light up here, it creates this
magnificent feeling.  After you come up

170.31.text:
Room.  I think it's quite easy to
understand why it's called the Green

173.47.text: Drawing Room.  The walls have always been hung with green

176.78.text:
silk and its replaced about every
thirty years.  You can also see here,

180.84.text:
green upholstered furniture and
green Serves porcelain on the various

186.11.text: different mantelpieces and on cabinets around the room.   Now, one of my

here which shows three daughters of

you reach the throne room. 
The throne of Her Majesty The Queen

220.55.text:
Elizabeth II is on the left and that of her

224.85.text:
Edinburgh, is on the right.  What makes
the room so special is the

theatricality is everywhere.  There are
swags of curtains that look like

236.88.text: curtains that close onto a stage, you've got these amazing sparkling chandeliers, that

now are electric light, but originally
when this room was built would have been

Picture Gallery at Buckingham Palace,

248.68.text:
which is an incredibly long room that
was created by knocking through three

254.22.text:
rooms in the original Buckingham House.
Right in the middle of the Palace, this

257.61.text:

because he wanted to display his amazing

262.75.text:

absolutely loved painting
